reference.title: Typical Usage Scenarios for Distributed Monitoring

section.p: The correct distributed strategy for your environment depends on network security restrictions, as well as scale. Contact if you are unsure which option best suits your enterprise.
Typical setup scenarios for using multiple hubs and collectors are shown in the following table:

row.entry: This setup requires only a single server, and is the most common deployment type. You would most likely use this configuration if you need to monitor fewer than 1000 devices, and your master server has direct network access to all of the monitored devices.

This setup requires two servers, and is the most basic distributed setup. The primary benefit of this configuration over the local hub/local collector configuration is that the master server does no collection. This frees resources, optimizing the server's ability to perform its central role of database server and Web interface.

This is the most common distributed configuration. You might use this configuration to scale to monitor more than 1000 devices. Depending on the hardware of the collectors, it is possible to monitor up to 1000 devices for each collector using this configuration. You might also use this configuration to handle differing network security policies. Often, your master server will not have access to all of the devices you need to monitor. In this case you can set up a remote collector with the required network access.
This configuration is for large installations only. For cases in which you have more than five collectors, you should consider deploying one or more hub servers to handle them.
